avalancheActivity.comment:
Over a wide area 80 to 120 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last few days above approximately 2000 m. The large quantity of fresh snow of the weekend as well as the wind slabs formed during the snowfall can be released easily or naturally above approximately 1900 m.
Already many large and, in isolated cases, very large dry and wet avalanches have been released on Monday.
As a consequence of falling temperatures, the natural avalanche activity will gradually decrease. Some large and, in isolated cases, very large natural avalanches are, however, further not ruled out. They can occur in particular in starting zones where previous releases have taken place.
Ski touring and other off-piste activities, including snowshoe hiking, call for great caution and restraint.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Large quantities of fresh snow and the wind-drifted snow of the weekend represent the main danger. At intermediate and high altitudes the situation is very dangerous.

snowpackStructure.comment: As a consequence of snowfall and the strong easterly wind, the snow drift accumulations have increased in size at the weekend. New snow is lying on soft layers. This snow is poorly bonded with the old snowpack in many places. In some places new snow is lying on a moist old snowpack.

tendency.comment:
The avalanche danger will decrease gradually.
Tuesday: Some new snow to above approximately 900 m.

avalancheActivity.comment:
Over a wide area 60 to 100 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last few days above approximately 2000 m.

The large quantity of fresh snow and the large wind slabs can be released easily or naturally in all aspects and in all altitude zones.
Large avalanches are possible in starting zones where no previous releases have taken place.
Ski touring and other off-piste activities, including snowshoe hiking, call for great caution and restraint. Snow sport activities outside marked and open pistes call for great caution and restraint.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Large quantities of fresh snow and the wind-drifted snow of the weekend represent the main danger. At intermediate and high altitudes the situation is very dangerous.

snowpackStructure.comment: As a consequence of heavy snowfall and the moderate to strong wind, the snowpack could not consolidate during the last few days. The new snow is poorly bonded with the old snowpack in many places. As a consequence of snowfall and the occasionally strong southerly wind, the snow drift accumulations have increased in size at the weekend.

tendency.comment:
The avalanche danger will decrease gradually.
Tuesday: Some new snow to above approximately 900 m.

avalancheActivity.comment:
Over a wide area 50 to 80 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last few days above approximately 2000 m. The large quantity of fresh snow of the weekend as well as the wind slabs formed during the snowfall can be released easily or naturally above approximately 1900 m.
Large and, in isolated cases, very large dry and wet avalanches have been released on Monday.
As a consequence of falling temperatures, the natural avalanche activity will gradually decrease. Some large and, in isolated cases, very large natural avalanches are, however, further not ruled out. They can occur in particular in starting zones where previous releases have taken place.
Ski touring and other off-piste activities, including snowshoe hiking, call for great caution and restraint.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Large quantities of fresh snow and the wind-drifted snow of the weekend represent the main danger. At intermediate and high altitudes the situation is very dangerous.

snowpackStructure.comment: As a consequence of snowfall and the occasionally strong easterly wind, the snow drift accumulations have increased in size at the weekend. New snow is lying on soft layers. This snow is poorly bonded with the old snowpack in many places. In some places new snow is lying on a moist old snowpack.

tendency.comment: The avalanche danger will decrease gradually.

avalancheActivity.comment:
Over a wide area 25 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last few days. As a consequence of the moderate to strong wind, fresh snow drift accumulations formed. These can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects and generally above the tree line.
The wind slabs are to be found especially adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

The current avalanche situation calls for extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
avalancheActivity.highlights: The fresh snow and the wind slabs represent the main danger. The current avalanche situation calls for caution and restraint.

snowpackStructure.comment:
The moderate wind has transported the old snow.
Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on the soft surface of an old snowpack. Towards its base, the snowpack is unfavourably layered and has a loosely bonded surface.

tendency.comment: The avalanche danger will decrease gradually.
